questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of joint pain, a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, and recent lab tests indicating renal involvement. These symptoms suggest she is most likely experiencing which type of disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

 

Option A:

 

SLE is characterized by immune complex-mediated tissue damage, which is a hallmark of Type III hypersensitivity. The symptoms described, including joint pain, a characteristic malar rash, and renal involvement, are classic for SLE.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: It is typically a Type I hypersensitivity reaction, not immune complex mediated.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis: Although it involves the immune system, it's more associated with autoantibodies (Type III) and Type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Goodpasture's syndrome: It's a Type II hypersensitivity disorder characterized by antibodies against glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLE is characterized by immune complex-mediated tissue damage, which is a hallmark of Type III hypersensitivity. The symptoms described, including joint pain, a characteristic malar rash, and renal involvement, are classic for SLE.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p176-79, 2/e p185

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with tight, hardened skin on her fingers and face, and difficulty swallowing. Which of the following conditions, associated with her symptoms, is most likely to show positive anti-centromere antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scleroderma

 

Option D:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with Scleroderma, particularly the limited cutaneous form (CREST syndrome), characterized by calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia.

 

Scleroderma (Systemic sclerosis) is of two types:

 

  •  Diffuse scleroderma: Autoantibodies against DNA topoisomerase I (anti-Scl 70) is elevated
  •  Limited scleroderma: ↑Anticentromere antibody, characterized by CREST syndrome—calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Drug induced lupus: Typically associated with anti-histone antibodies.

 

Option B. SLE: Characterized by a wide array of antibodies, but not specifically anti-centromere antibodies.

 

Option C. Sjögren's syndrome: Associated with anti-SSA (Ro) and anti-SSB (La) antibodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The presence of anti-centromere antibodies is strongly associated with Scleroderma, specifically the limited cutaneous form of the disease, often referred to as CREST syndrome.

 

Immunofluorescence Patterns

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p191

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a malar rash, joint pain, and renal impairment. A positive ANA is crucial for the diagnosis of which of the following conditions in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  SLE

 

Option A:

 

A positive ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) test is almost always required for the diagnosis of SLE. It is one of the most sensitive tests for SLE, although not highly specific.

 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

 

  • Autoantibodies are produced against various tissue antigens such as DNA, nuclear protein, RBC and platelet membranes
  • Women (20-40 years of age) are commonly affected; female to male ratio is 10:1
  • Immune complexes (self Ag-autoAb) are formed; which are deposited in various organs
  • Major symptoms: Fever, butterfly rash over the cheeks, arthritis, pleurisy, and kidney dysfunction
  • Antibodies - 
    • Antinuclear antibody (ANA): Positive in >90% of cases, used as screening method 
    • Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA): Highly specific, used for confirmation of cases
    • Anti-Sm antibodies.
  • Lupus band test: It is a direct immunofluorescence test, can detect deposits of immunoglobulins and complement proteins in the patient’s skin

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sjögren's syndrome: ANA can be positive but is not a diagnostic requirement.

 

Option C. Drug induced lupus: Characterized by anti-histone antibodies.

 

Option D. Scleroderma: ANA can be positive but is not solely diagnostic.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) test is one of the most sensitive tests for diagnosis of SLE, Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) is the Highly specific, used for confirmation of cases

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p192

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symmetrical joint pain, particularly in the hands. Rheumatoid arthritis is suspected. All of the following immune components are involved in RA except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Neutrophil

 

Option A:

 

While neutrophils can be present in the inflamed synovium, they are not a key driver in the pathogenesis of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). RA primarily involves macrophages, lymphocytes, and antibodies (rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies).

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) - 

 

  • Group of autoantibodies against the host IgG antibodies are produced called RA factor.
  • It is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc region of IgG
  • Women (40–60 years of age) affected
  • Autoantibodies bind to circulating IgG, forming IgM-IgG complexes that are deposited in the joints and can activate the complement cascade
  • Major symptoms:
  •  Main feature: Arthritis (chronic inflammation of the joints, begins at synovium; most common joints involved are-small joints of the hands, feet and cervical spine)
  • Other features: Hematologic, cardiovascular, and respiratory systems are also frequently affected

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Actively involved in the inflammation and destruction in RA.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte: T and B lymphocytes play a crucial role in RA pathology.

 

Option D. Antibody: Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies are characteristic of RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with involvement of Macrophage, Lymphocyte and IgM Antibody.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p191

choices.text: Antibody to anti- Ca receptor
Blockage of nerve conduction through myoneural junction

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. Based on her symptoms, which of the following is true about Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Antibody to Ach (Acetylcholine) receptor

 

Option A:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by the presence of antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission and muscle weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Antibody to anti- Ca receptor: Not associated with Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Option C. Ach is not secreted: Acetylcholine is secreted but its action is impaired due to antibody binding.

 

Option D. Blockage of nerve conduction: The primary issue is at the neuromuscular junction, not nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathophysiology of Myasthenia Gravis - involves antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptor, leading to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology, 2/e p191

questions.text: A researcher is studying the concept of immunologically privileged sites in the human body, where certain tissues are protected from the immune response. Which of the following is considered an immunologically privileged site?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Seminiferous tubules

 

Option A:

 

Immunologically privileged sites are areas in the body where immune responses are diminished or absent, preventing autoimmune responses against the body's own tissues. The seminiferous tubules in the testes are an example of such a site. They are designed to protect spermatogenic cells from autoimmune reactions. The blood-testis barrier isolates the developing gametes from the immune system, as these cells express antigens that are different from those on the body's somatic cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Area postrema: Part of the brain that controls vomiting, not an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option C. Optic nerve: Not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option D. Loop of Henle: Part of the kidney involved in urine concentration, not an immunologically privileged site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The seminiferous tubules in the testes are considered an immunologically privileged site. This is due to the blood-testis barrier, which protects sperm from potential autoimmune attacks as sperm antigens are not exposed to the immune system during immune tolerance development.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p184, 2/e p189 , CNS infection and immune privilege- Forrester, J.V., McMenamin, P.G. & Dando, S.J. CNS infection and immune privilege. Nat Rev Neurosci 19, 655–671 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41583-018-0070-8

choices.text: The presence of forbidden clones
Negative selection of T-cells in the thymus
Inappropriate expression of MHC proteins

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of joint pain and skin rashes. Her medical history is notable for autoimmune thyroiditis. On examination, she has symmetrical joint swelling and a butterfly rash on her face. Laboratory tests reveal high levels of antinuclear antibodies (ANA). The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of an autoimmune disorder. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of autoimmunity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negative selection of T-cells in the thymus

 

Option C:

 

Negative selection of T-cells in the thymus is a process that eliminates T-cells that are strongly reactive to self-antigens, thereby preventing autoimmunity. This process is crucial for maintaining self-tolerance and does not cause autoimmunity. Therefore, it is the least likely factor to cause autoimmunity in the given scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The presence of forbidden clones: Forbidden clones are self-reactive lymphocytes that escape deletion. Their activation can lead to autoimmunity.


Option B. Expression of cryptic antigens: These are self-antigens not usually exposed to the immune system. Their exposure can trigger an autoimmune response.


Option D. Inappropriate expression of MHC proteins: Abnormal MHC expression can present self-antigens in an unusual context, potentially triggering an autoimmune response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Negative selection of T-cell is a process by which self reactive T-cells are killed in thymus–this is one of the mechanism of preventing development of Autoimmunity.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p150, 2/e p189-190
